airline_graph <- airline_graph %>%
  activate(nodes) %>%
  mutate(degree = centrality_degree())

title: networks: airlines dataset
text:
conclusion
Overall, the airline network is concentrated around a few highly connected airports, while most airports have only a small number of connections. These highly connected airports also tend to have higher traffic, showing that network connectivity and airport activity are closely related.

title: karate club dataset
text:
show me the code
library(ggformula)
library(tidyverse)
library(igraph) # Network Analysis Library (Handle data and Viz)
library(tidygraph) # For Network "Manipulation"
library(ggraph) # For Network Visualization
library(graphlayouts) # For Network Visualization, more layouts and themes


library(visNetwork) # For Interactive Network Visualization
library(igraphdata) # For "Network" Datasets
library(sand) # Statistical Analysis of Networks Data 



data("karate")
karate

title: karate club dataset
text:
plotting directly with ggraph

set.seed(42)

ggraph(karate, layout = "fr") +
  geom_edge_link(alpha = 0.3, colour = "grey70") +
  geom_node_point(size = 4, shape = 21, fill = "steelblue") +
  theme_void()








This network shows the overall structure of relationships within the karate club. The layout reveals two main clusters of members connected by a few central individuals. Some members are located at the centre with many connections, while others are positioned on the edges with only a few links. This suggests that interactions in the club are not evenly distributed and depend on a few key members.

title: karate club dataset
text:
adding degree centrality

karate_graph <- as_tbl_graph(karate) %>%
  activate(nodes) %>%
  mutate(degree = centrality_degree())

plotting the graph

set.seed(42)

karate_graph %>%
  ggraph(layout = "fr") +
  geom_edge_link(alpha = 0.3, colour = "grey70") +
  geom_node_point(aes(size = degree, fill = degree),
                  shape = 21) +
  scale_fill_distiller(palette = "Spectral") +
  theme_void()








In this visualisation, node size and colour represent degree centrality. A small number of members appear larger and brighter, indicating that they have many connections and play a more central role in the network. Most members are smaller and located towards the outside, meaning they interact with fewer people. This shows that the club’s social structure is influenced by a few highly connected individuals.

title: karate club dataset
text:
conclusion
Overall, the karate club network shows that relationships are concentrated around a few central members, and the network naturally forms two groups. This suggests that social interactions within the club are shaped both by key individuals and by divisions between member groups.

title: maps: restaurants
text:
getting MG Road data
i will now specify a bounding box to get MG road base map data

title: maps: restaurants
text:
specifying the bounding box

# https://boundingbox.klokantech.com CSV:
# 77.594,12.965753,77.610464,12.979926
bbox_1 <- matrix(c(77.594, 12.965753, 77.610464, 12.979926), 
                 byrow = FALSE, 
                 nrow = 2,
                 ncol = 2, 
                 dimnames = list(c("x", "y"), c("min", "max")))
bbox_1

       min      max
x 77.59400 77.61046
y 12.96575 12.97993


now i will download the roads and buildings inside the bounding box

#| label: download-buildings
#| eval: false

# Get all buildings within my bbox

dat_buildings <-
  osmdata::opq(bbox = bbox_1) %>% 
  osmdata::add_osm_feature(key = "building") %>% 
  osmdata_sf() %>% 
  purrr::pluck("osm_polygons")


#| label: download-roads
#| eval: false

# Get all residential roads within my bbox
dat_roads <- 
  osmdata::opq(bbox = bbox_1) %>% 
  osmdata::add_osm_feature(key = "highway") %>% 
  osmdata_sf() %>% 
  purrr::pluck("osm_lines")

now i will save the data locally

#| eval: false

sf::st_write(dat_buildings,
             dsn = "../myA3assignment/data/gpkg-data/buildings.gpkg",
             append = F,
             quiet = F)

  `../myA3assignment/data/gpkg-data/buildings.gpkg' using driver `GPKG'

#| eval: false

             dsn = "../myA3assignment/data/gpkg-data/roads.gpkg",
             append = F,
             quiet = F)

title: maps: restaurants
text:
creating the restaurant dataset

restaurants <- tibble(
  name = c(
    "Homiga",
    "Amintiri",
    "Nagarjuna",
    "Kuuraku",
    "Sriracha",
    "The Pizza Bakery",
    "Sunny's",
    "Ebony",
    "Yauatcha",
    "Lavonne"
  ),
  
  cuisine = c(
    "Pan-Asian",
    "Dessert",
    "South Indian",
    "Pan-Asian",
    "Pan-Asian",
    "Italian",
    "Italian",
    "Pan-Asian",
    "Pan-Asian",
    "Dessert"
  ),
  
  lon = c(
    77.60774,
    77.60730,
    77.60618,
    77.60768,
    77.59589,
    77.60749,
    77.59797,
    77.60583,
    77.59628,
    77.60703
  ),
  
  lat = c(
    12.97362,
    12.97270,
    12.96883,
    12.97355,
    12.97157,
    12.97283,
    12.97118,
    12.97497,
    12.97184,
    12.97399
  )
)

restaurants

# A tibble: 10 × 4
   name             cuisine        lon   lat
   <chr>            <chr>        <dbl> <dbl>
 1 Homiga           Pan-Asian     77.6  13.0
 2 Amintiri         Dessert       77.6  13.0
 3 Nagarjuna        South Indian  77.6  13.0
 4 Kuuraku          Pan-Asian     77.6  13.0
 5 Sriracha         Pan-Asian     77.6  13.0
 6 The Pizza Bakery Italian       77.6  13.0
 7 Sunny's          Italian       77.6  13.0
 8 Ebony            Pan-Asian     77.6  13.0
 9 Yauatcha         Pan-Asian     77.6  13.0
10 Lavonne          Dessert       77.6  13.0

title: maps: restaurants
text:
converting restaurants to sf

restaurant_sf <- sfheaders::sf_point(
  restaurants,
  x = "lon",
  y = "lat",
  keep = TRUE   
)

# match CRS with buildings

restaurant_sf <- restaurant_sf %>%
  st_set_crs(st_crs(buildings))

restaurant_sf

Simple feature collection with 10 features and 2 fields
Geometry type: POINT
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 77.59589 ymin: 12.96883 xmax: 77.60774 ymax: 12.97497
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84
               name      cuisine                  geometry
1            Homiga    Pan-Asian POINT (77.60774 12.97362)
2          Amintiri      Dessert   POINT (77.6073 12.9727)
3         Nagarjuna South Indian POINT (77.60618 12.96883)
4           Kuuraku    Pan-Asian POINT (77.60768 12.97355)
5          Sriracha    Pan-Asian POINT (77.59589 12.97157)
6  The Pizza Bakery      Italian POINT (77.60749 12.97283)
7           Sunny's      Italian POINT (77.59797 12.97118)
8             Ebony    Pan-Asian POINT (77.60583 12.97497)
9          Yauatcha    Pan-Asian POINT (77.59628 12.97184)
10          Lavonne      Dessert POINT (77.60703 12.97399)

title: maps: restaurants
section: renaming the geometry column to match buildings/roads
text:
renaming the geometry column to match buildings/roads

restaurant_sf <- restaurant_sf %>%
  rename(geom = geometry)

title: maps: restaurants
text:
plotting the map

gf_sf(data = buildings, geometry = ~ geom, fill = "grey90") %>% 
  
  gf_sf(data = roads, geometry = ~ geom, color = "skyblue", size = 0.5) %>% 
  
  gf_sf(data = restaurant_sf, geometry = ~ geom, color = ~ cuisine, size = 2.5) %>% 
  
  gf_theme(theme = theme_classic())

title: maps: restaurants
text:
conclusion
This map highlights my favourite restaurants around the MG Road area in Bangalore. By colour-coding the locations based on cuisine, the visualization reflects the diversity of dining options available in a relatively small area. The map also shows how this part of the city functions as a dense social and cultural hub, with a mix of different food experiences concentrated around key streets like Church Street and St. Marks Road.

  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'

title: migration
text:
map 1 - base world map

gf_sf(data = World, fill = "grey90", color = "grey70", size = 0.2) %>%
  gf_theme(theme = theme_classic())








This map shows the base world layer used as the reference for the analysis. The World dataset from the tmap package was plotted using gf_sf(). Countries are displayed in light grey with thin boundaries to provide geographic context for the migration data shown in the following maps.

title: migration
text:
map 2 - migration routes

gf_sf(data = World, fill = "grey90", color = "grey70", size = 0.2) %>%
  gf_sf(data = rose_lines, color = "red", size = 0.5, alpha = 0.9) %>%
  gf_theme(theme = theme_classic())








This map displays the migration routes of the Common Rosefinch using the line shapefile. The red lines represent movement paths connecting recorded locations. These lines show the overall spatial extent and direction of migration patterns at a global scale.

title: migration
text:
map 3 - observation locations

gf_sf(data = World, fill = "grey90", color = "grey70", size = 0.2) %>%
  gf_sf(data = rose_points, color = "blue", size = 0.3, alpha = 0.5) %>%
  gf_theme(theme = theme_classic())








This map shows the recorded observation locations of the Common Rosefinch. Each blue point represents an individual geographic record from the point shapefile. The points illustrate the overall spatial distribution of observations across the study area.

title: migration
text:
conclusion
Together, the maps present both the individual observation locations and the movement connections between them. The overlap between points and routes indicates consistent migration patterns across the recorded locations.

title: About

About this site

title: myA3assignment
text:
This website presents a collection of my data visualisation projects created for the A3 assignment. Each project explores a different dataset and uses visual methods to communicate patterns, relationships, and insights.
Use the links below to navigate to any project you would like to explore.

title: myA3assignment
text:
This website presents a collection of my data visualisation projects created for the A3 assignment. Each project explores a different dataset and uses visual methods to communicate patterns, relationships, and insights.
Use the links below to navigate to any project you would like to explore.

title: myA3assignment
text:
Projects

1. Airline Network Analysis
This project explores airline connectivity using network visualization techniques. Airports are represented as nodes and flight routes as edges, allowing the structure of the airline network to be examined. The visualization highlights major hubs, connectivity patterns, and the overall structure of air travel networks.
View Project



2. Zachary Karate Club Network
This project visualizes the Zachary Karate Club dataset to study social network structure. The network represents relationships between members and illustrates community formation, group splits, and central individuals. The visualization demonstrates key network concepts such as clusters, centrality, and social structure.
View Project



3. Favourite Restaurants around MG Road
An interactive spatial visualization of my favourite restaurants in the MG Road area of Bangalore. The locations are mapped using OpenStreetMap data and colour-coded by cuisine to show the diversity of food options in this urban hub.
View Project



4. Bird Migration Map
This project visualizes the migration patterns of a rosefinch bird species using movement data downloaded from Movebank.
View Project
